stories.title: Andrej Karpathy: Software in the era of AI [video]
stories.author: sandslash
stories.article_summary: Article content too short to summarize effectively.

agreement_points: There is a consensus that AI tools like Claude 4 and Gemini are currently not meeting user expectations, which is significant for developers and businesses relying on these technologies.
disagreement_points: Debate exists around the reliability of AI systems, with some users feeling that current tools are insufficient, while others may argue that improvements are on the horizon.
comments_analysis.sentiment_summary: The discussion reflects a growing frustration within the developer community regarding the reliability and accuracy of AI tools like Claude 4 and Gemini. Users express disappointment over the brittleness of these systems, particularly in practical applications such as code generation and documentation support. The sentiment indicates a demand for more robust solutions that can meet the expectations of users who depend on these technologies for their work.
comments_analysis.top_comment_summary: The commenter highlights the limitations of AI systems like Claude 4 in practical coding tasks, noting that despite prompting for accuracy, the AI produced inefficient code that overlooked basic logic. They emphasize the brittleness of current AI technologies in real-world applications, contrasting it with the potential for improvement through automated testing in software engineering.

specific_numbers: The comment mentions the brittleness of AI systems, indicating a common frustration among developers who rely on these tools for practical applications, emphasizing the need for better reliability in AI outputs.
tools_mentioned: Claude 4 is discussed as an AI tool for code generation, highlighting the limitations in its ability to handle simple tasks like EXIF normalization, which reflects on the current state of AI capabilities and user expectations.
performance_data: The performance of Gemini as a chatbot is criticized for failing to accurately represent company information, which underscores the importance of accuracy in AI tools for business applications.

resource_requirements: The need for reliable AI tools is emphasized, as failures can lead to wasted time and resources, impacting productivity and trust in AI solutions.

compatibility_issues: The comment about Gemini's failures suggests that compatibility with existing documentation and workflows is crucial for effective AI tool deployment.

strong_agreements: There is a consensus that AI tools like Claude 4 and Gemini are currently not meeting user expectations, which is significant for developers and businesses relying on these technologies.
major_disagreements: Debate exists around the reliability of AI systems, with some users feeling that current tools are insufficient, while others may argue that improvements are on the horizon.

market_trends: The trend of integrating AI into business processes is evident, but the dissatisfaction with current tools indicates a potential gap in the market for more reliable solutions.

failed_attempts: The failure of Gemini to accurately handle company-specific tasks illustrates the challenges businesses face when adopting AI tools, highlighting the need for thorough testing before implementation.

actionable_advice: Businesses should thoroughly evaluate AI tools for their specific needs and ensure they can handle essential tasks before full deployment to avoid operational disruptions.
what_to_avoid: Avoid relying solely on AI tools for critical tasks without human oversight, as demonstrated by the failures noted in the comments.

top_comments.author: mentalgear
top_comments.text:
Meanwhile, I asked this morning Claude 4 to write a simple EXIF normalizer. After two rounds of prompting it to double-check its code, I still had to point out that it makes no sense to load the entire image for re-orientating if the EXIF orientation is fine in the first place.
Vibe vs reality, and anyone actually working in the space daily can attest how brittle these systems are.
Maybe this changes in SWE with more automated tests in verifiable simulators, but the real world is far to complex to simulate in its vastness.

top_comments.author: diggan
top_comments.text:
> Meanwhile
What do you mean "meanwhile", that's exactly (among other things) the kind of stuff he's talking about? The various frictions and how you need to approach it
> anyone actually working in the space
Is this trying to say that Karpathy doesn't "actually work" with LLMs or in the ML space?
I feel like your whole comment is just reacting to the title of the YouTube video, rather than actually thinking and reflecting on the content itself.

top_comments.author: ApeWithCompiler
top_comments.text:
A manager in our company introduced Gemini as a chat bot coupled to our documentation.
> It failed to write out our company name.The rest was flawed with hallucinations also, hardly worth to mention.
I wish this is a rage bait towards others, but what should me feelings be? After all this is the tool thats sold to me, I am expected to work with.

top_comments.author: coreyh14444
top_comments.text: https://theeducationist.info/everything-amazing-nobody-happy...

top_comments.author: ramon156
top_comments.text: The real question is how long it'll take until they're not brittle

top_comments.author: kubb
top_comments.text: Or will they ever be reliable. Your question is already making an assumption.

top_comments.author: diggan
top_comments.text: They're reliable already if you change the way you approach them. These probabilistic token generators probably never will be "reliable" if you expect them to 100% always output exactly what you had in mind, without iterating in user-space (the prompts).

top_comments.author: sensanaty
top_comments.text:
There's also those instances where Microsoft unleashed Copilot on the .NET repo, and it resulted in the most hilariously terrible PRs that required the maintainers to basically tell Copilot every single step it should take to fix the issue. They were basically writing the PRs themselves at that point, except doing it through an intermediary that was much dumber, slower and less practical than them.
And don't get me started on my own experiences with these things, and no, I'm not a luddite, I've tried my damndest and have followed all the cutting-edge advice you see posted on HN and elsewhere.
Time and time again, the reality of these tools falls flat on their face while people like Andrej hype things up as if we're 5 minutes away from having Claude become Skynet or whatever, or as he puts it, before we enter the world of "Software 3.0" (coincidentally totally unrelated to Web 3.0 and the grift we had to endure there, I'm sure).
To intercept the common arguments,
- no I'm not saying LLMs are useless or have no usecases
- yes there's a possibility if you extrapolate by current trends (https://xkcd.com/605/) that they indeed will be Skynet
- yes I've tried the latest and greatest model released 7 minutes ago to the best of my ability
- yes I've tried giving it prompts so detailed a literal infant could follow along and accomplish the task
- yes I've fiddled with providing it more/less context
- yes I've tried keeping it to a single chat rather than multiple chats, as well as vice versa
- yes I've tried Claude Code, Gemini Pro 2.5 With Deep Research, Roocode, Cursor, Junie, etc.
- yes I've tried having 50 different "agents" running and only choosing the best output form the lot.
I'm sure there's a new gotcha being written up as we speak, probably something along the lines of "Well for me it doubled my productivity!" and that's great, I'm genuinely happy for you if that's the case, but for me and my team who have been trying diligently to use these tools for anything that wasn't a microscopic toy project, it has fallen apart time and time again.
The idea of an application UI or god forbid an entire fucking Operating System being run via these bullshit generators is just laughable to me, it's like I'm living on a different planet.

top_comments.author: darqis
top_comments.text:
when I started coding at the age of 11 in machine code and assembly on the C64, the dream was to create software that creates software. Nowadays it's almost reality, almost because the devil is always in the details. When you're used to write code, writing code is relatively fast. You need this knowledge to debug issues with generated code. However you're now telling AI to fix the bugs in the generated code. I see it kind of like machine code becomes overlaid with asm which becomes overlaid with C or whatever higher level language, which then uses dogma/methodology like MVC and such and on top of that there's now the AI input and generation layer. But it's not widely available. Affording more than 1 computer is a luxury. Many households are even struggling to get by. When you see those what 5 7 Mac Minis, which normal average Joe can afford that or does even have to knowledge to construct an LLM at home? I don't. This is a toy for rich people. Just like with public clouds like AWS, GCP I left out, because the cost is too high and running my own is also too expensive and there are cheaper alternatives that not only cost less but also have way less overhead.
What would be interesting to see is what those kids produced with their vibe coding.

stories.title: From LLM to AI Agent: What's the Real Journey Behind AI System Development?
stories.author: codelink
stories.article_summary: The article discusses the evolution of AI systems, particularly focusing on Large Language Models (LLMs), Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG), AI workflows, and AI agents. It emphasizes that while AI agents offer autonomy, simpler solutions often suffice for many applications, such as a resume-screening tool. For instance, an LLM can classify resumes as "Passed" or "Failed" using one-shot prompting, while RAG enhances this by integrating internal data for improved decision-making. Key insights include starting with simple workflows and only adopting AI agents when necessary, as well as prioritizing reliability over capability in production systems. Notably, the article suggests employing APIs for automation, such as connecting to email and calendar services to streamline recruitment processes.

market_signals.description: Increased adoption of LLMs for recruitment tools.

competitive_intelligence.strategic_moves: Focus on RAG for enhanced decision-making.
competitive_intelligence.market_impact: Increased competition in AI recruitment solutions.

investment_insights.investment_angle: Growing demand for AI in HR tech.
investment_insights.risk_factors: Market saturation and rapid tech changes.

actionable_takeaways: Invest in developing LLM-based tools for recruitment.
Integrate APIs to automate recruitment workflows.

key_metrics.growth_indicators: Adoption of AI tools in recruitment increasing.
key_metrics.market_size: HR tech market projected to grow significantly.

stories.title: Show HN: Claude Code Usage Monitor – real-time tracker to dodge usage cut-offs
stories.author: Maciej-roboblog
stories.article_summary: The Claude Code Usage Monitor is a real-time terminal tool designed for tracking Claude AI token usage, offering features such as updates every 3 seconds, visual progress bars, and smart predictions for token depletion based on current burn rates. It supports multiple plans—Pro (~7,000 tokens), Max5 (~35,000), and Max20 (~140,000)—and includes an auto-detection mode that switches to a custom limit when the Pro threshold is exceeded. Users can customize reset times and time zones, with default reset times set for every 5 hours after the first message in a session. The tool can be installed using Python 3.6+ and npm, with a simple command like `./ccusage_monitor.py --plan pro` for basic usage. As stated in the article, "Start Early: Begin monitoring when you start a new session" is a key actionable insight for effective management of token usage.

agreement_points: There is a consensus on the need for a simple command to track usage against plans, indicating a desire for transparency and ease of use in managing resources.
comments_analysis.sentiment_summary: The discussion reveals a strong desire among users for improved management of their development tools, particularly regarding the installation and tracking of resource usage. Users express frustration over the fragility of global installations and the complexity of managing multiple environments. The introduction of an Auto Mode with machine learning capabilities is seen as a positive step towards more efficient resource management.
comments_analysis.top_comment_summary: The commenter expresses a desire for a straightforward command to check their usage against their plan, while also noting frustration that Python is required for a tool that is primarily based on Node.js.

tools_mentioned: Node.js is discussed as a tool that requires global installation which can lead to version conflicts, making it fragile for users who rely on consistent environments across multiple tools.

resource_requirements: Python and Node.js are mentioned as resources that users prefer not to duplicate for every tool, as this could lead to increased storage usage and management complexity.

setup_instructions: Installing tools in a self-contained manner is suggested to avoid duplication of Python/Node, which is important for maintaining a clean development environment and preventing conflicts.
compatibility_issues: Global installation of Node CLI tools can break easily with version changes, which users need to be aware of to maintain tool functionality and avoid disruptions in their workflow.

strong_agreements: There is a consensus on the need for a simple command to track usage against plans, indicating a desire for transparency and ease of use in managing resources.

company_strategies: The introduction of an Auto Mode with DuckDB that leverages machine learning to understand token limits reflects a strategic move towards more intelligent resource management, which could enhance user satisfaction and retention.

actionable_advice: Users are advised to consolidate their Python and Node.js installations to prevent conflicts and improve tool reliability, which can lead to a smoother development experience.
what_to_avoid: Avoid global installations of CLI tools without version management, as this can lead to instability in tool performance and user frustration.

top_comments.text: Thank you! For me, I wish it was just a simple command that outputs how much I have used out of my plan already. Also I feel it’s a bummer that I need python when CC is a node.js tool.

I guess I don't want to duplicate Python/Node for every tool, but I also don't want it to be fragile. And this wants a Node CLI tool installed globally, which I've found breaks easily with changing versions.

stories.title: TI to invest $60B to manufacture foundational semiconductors in the U.S.
stories.author: TMWNN
stories.article_summary: Texas Instruments (TI) has announced a historic investment of over $60 billion to expand semiconductor manufacturing in the U.S., marking the largest such investment in the nation's history. This initiative includes the construction of seven semiconductor fabs across mega-sites in Texas and Utah, which will create over 60,000 jobs. TI's Sherman site alone will see up to $40 billion allocated for four fabs (SM1, SM2, SM3, and SM4), with SM1 and SM2 already in progress. CEO Haviv Ilan stated, “TI is building dependable, low-cost 300mm capacity at scale,” emphasizing the critical role these chips play in various sectors, from automotive to healthcare. Partnerships with leading companies such as Apple, Ford, Medtronic, NVIDIA, and SpaceX highlight TI's commitment to driving innovation in American manufacturing and technology.

agreement_points: There is a general skepticism in the community regarding corporate announcements of large investments, as seen in the reference to a previous $500 billion AI investment that has not materialized, indicating a distrust in corporate promises.
disagreement_points: The community is divided on the effectiveness of government and corporate partnerships, with some believing they are merely marketing ploys while others see potential benefits, reflecting differing views on accountability and transparency.
comments_analysis.sentiment_summary: The discussion reflects a deep skepticism towards corporate promises, particularly in the context of significant financial investments. Commenters highlight the example of Texas Instruments, questioning how they can afford large investments given their current market cap. The community also draws parallels to a previous $500 billion AI initiative that failed to deliver, indicating a broader concern about the reliability of corporate commitments and the potential consequences for innovation and accountability in the tech industry.
comments_analysis.top_comment_summary: The commenter highlights concerns about Texas Instruments' financial strategy, suggesting that their significant investment announcement may be unrealistic given their current market cap of approximately $170 billion, raising doubts about the company's ability to follow through.

specific_numbers: Texas Instruments has a market cap of approximately $170 billion, which raises concerns about their ability to invest a third of that value in new initiatives, highlighting the financial strain on large corporations when faced with significant investments.

strong_agreements: There is a general skepticism in the community regarding corporate announcements of large investments, as seen in the reference to a previous $500 billion AI investment that has not materialized, indicating a distrust in corporate promises.
major_disagreements: The community is divided on the effectiveness of government and corporate partnerships, with some believing they are merely marketing ploys while others see potential benefits, reflecting differing views on accountability and transparency.

market_trends: The trend of financialization in large corporations, as exemplified by Texas Instruments, suggests a shift away from long-term investments towards short-term financial gains, which could impact innovation and growth in the tech sector.
company_strategies: Texas Instruments' strategy of leveraging financialization raises questions about their future investments and sustainability, potentially putting them at a competitive disadvantage if they fail to innovate.

failed_attempts: The previous $500 billion AI initiative serves as a cautionary tale of failed corporate promises, emphasizing the need for accountability in corporate governance.

actionable_advice: Investors should critically evaluate corporate announcements and look for follow-up actions to gauge the sincerity of commitments, as past experiences suggest many promises may not be fulfilled.
what_to_avoid: Avoid taking corporate announcements at face value without seeking evidence of actual implementation, as this could lead to misguided investments.

How are they going to afford an investment thats ~1/3rd the value of the company? Seems like one of those announcements that no one follows up on to keep them honest?

top_comments.author: ryukoposting
top_comments.text: I find that the easiest way to suss out corporate political advertisements is to look for how they refer to the federal government. If they say "federal government" or "$NAME_OF_ACT" then there's usually at least an inkling of intent behind whatever they say next. If they say "$PRESIDENT administration" or "$PARTY_NAME," you can be certain you're reading a political advertisement.

Saudi Aramco was (just a few years ago) the largest non-gold asset, and isn't even Top 10 anymore.
If you want to read about similarities in Xerox's own hubris/downfall, Dealers of Lightning is one of my favorite non-fiction reads of the past few years (about their SFbay PARC Labs of the 70s/80s... and its failures to adapt).

stories.title: Six-month-old, solo-owned vibe coder Base44 sells to Wix for $80M cash
stories.author: myth_drannon
stories.article_summary: Israeli developer Maor Shlomo's vibe-coding startup, Base44, was acquired by Wix for $80 million just six months after its launch. Despite being a bootstrapped venture, Base44 rapidly grew to 250,000 users, generating $189,000 in profit by May, largely through word-of-mouth and Shlomo's social media presence. The platform enables users to create applications without coding by utilizing text prompts and supports various integrations, including email and analytics. Shlomo attributed the sale to the need for scaling beyond organic growth, stating, "the scale and volume we need is not something we can organically grow into," highlighting the potential of AI in startup productivity.

agreement_points: The community seems to agree on the impressive speed of the company's growth, reflecting a strong product-market fit and the ability to attract users quickly.
disagreement_points: There is debate over the sustainability of the product's success, with questions about its unique selling proposition and whether it can maintain its user base against competitors.
comments_analysis.sentiment_summary: The discussion reflects a mix of admiration for the rapid success of a product valued at $80M within six months and skepticism about its long-term viability in a competitive landscape. While some see potential in the existing user base and profitability, others question the uniqueness of the offering and whether it can sustain growth against numerous similar products. The community is intrigued by the implications of such rapid growth and the strategies employed to achieve it.
comments_analysis.top_comment_summary: The commenter highlights the remarkable achievement of selling a company for $80 million within just six months, contrasting it with their own inability to stand at that age, emphasizing the extraordinary nature of such success.

specific_numbers: $80M in sales within six months indicates a rapid market acceptance and potential for high demand, suggesting that the product has resonated well with users and could signify a lucrative business model.
tools_mentioned: Claude, as a wrapper, is being discussed in the context of its competitive advantage; understanding its unique features is crucial for evaluating its market position against similar products.
performance_data: The mention of profitability suggests that the product not only generates revenue but also manages costs effectively, which is vital for sustainability in a competitive market.

price_comparisons: The $80M valuation versus the cost of building a similar product from scratch highlights the potential for significant investment in development and marketing, which could lead to faster market penetration.
resource_requirements: Hiring 7 people indicates a need for diverse skills in development and marketing, which is essential for scaling the product effectively and meeting user demands.

strong_agreements: The community seems to agree on the impressive speed of the company's growth, reflecting a strong product-market fit and the ability to attract users quickly.
major_disagreements: There is debate over the sustainability of the product's success, with questions about its unique selling proposition and whether it can maintain its user base against competitors.

market_trends: The rapid valuation growth reflects a trend in tech startups achieving high valuations quickly, indicating a shift towards investor confidence in innovative solutions.
company_strategies: The strategy of leveraging existing technology (like Claude) rather than building from scratch suggests a focus on speed to market, which can provide a competitive edge.
competitive_landscape: The mention of a dozen similar products indicates a crowded market, highlighting the need for differentiation to avoid being overshadowed by competitors.

actionable_advice: Consider investing in unique features or user experience enhancements to differentiate from competitors, which could lead to sustained user engagement and loyalty.
what_to_avoid: Avoid underestimating the importance of a strong marketing strategy; failing to effectively communicate the product's unique benefits could lead to losing market share.

stories.title: Writing documentation for AI: best practices
stories.author: mooreds
stories.article_summary: The article emphasizes the importance of high-quality documentation for AI systems, particularly Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) frameworks like Kapa, which relies on well-structured content to generate accurate responses. Key components include a retriever that searches documentation, a vector database for storage, and a generator (LLM) that formulates answers. It underscores that "poor documentation doesn't just frustrate human readers; it directly degrades the quality of AI responses," highlighting the necessity for explicit and self-contained content chunks to improve AI accuracy. Actionable insights include using standardized semantic HTML, avoiding PDFs in favor of HTML or Markdown, and ensuring semantic clarity in URLs, which collectively enhance machine readability and retrieval efficiency.

agreement_points: There is a consensus that good documentation is essential for effective software development; this is supported by the observation that clear context and hierarchy improve usability.
disagreement_points: Some debate exists around the effectiveness of SEO tactics, with a division between those who believe in shortcuts versus those advocating for genuine content quality.
comments_analysis.sentiment_summary: The discussion emphasizes the importance of good documentation and coding practices, with a consensus that clear structure and context enhance usability and efficiency. While there are differing opinions on SEO tactics, the community agrees that foundational principles of quality content are essential for long-term success. Developers are increasingly recognizing the value of standard engineering practices, leading to more efficient workflows and improved outcomes.
comments_analysis.top_comment_summary: The commenter highlights the irony that creating AI-friendly documentation aligns closely with the principles of good documentation, such as clear context, structured hierarchy, and precise error messages.

specific_numbers: The emphasis on creating AI-friendly documentation highlights the importance of clear structure and context in documentation, which can significantly reduce onboarding time for new developers and improve overall productivity.
tools_mentioned: HTML elements are discussed in the context of SEO; proper use of these elements can enhance website visibility and user experience, which is crucial for attracting and retaining users.
performance_data: The mention of SEO practices indicates that while there are shortcuts to improve rankings, the foundational principles of good content remain essential for long-term success, impacting site traffic and engagement.

resource_requirements: The need for good documentation and SEO practices suggests that investing time in these areas can lead to better user engagement and lower support costs in the long run.
efficiency_gains: Adopting standard software engineering practices can lead to significant efficiency improvements, as developers find that breaking down problems into smaller parts allows for faster and more effective coding.

setup_instructions: Creating documentation that is AI-friendly requires a structured approach; skipping this can lead to confusion and inefficiencies in both development and user experience.

strong_agreements: There is a consensus that good documentation is essential for effective software development; this is supported by the observation that clear context and hierarchy improve usability.
major_disagreements: Some debate exists around the effectiveness of SEO tactics, with a division between those who believe in shortcuts versus those advocating for genuine content quality.

market_trends: The trend towards AI-friendly documentation reflects a broader movement in the tech industry towards efficiency and clarity, which can lead to competitive advantages for companies that adopt these practices.

working_setups: Developers report that structuring code logically allows for easier maintenance and faster development cycles, demonstrating the practical benefits of applying good engineering practices.

actionable_advice: Invest in creating clear and structured documentation; this will improve team efficiency and reduce onboarding time for new developers.
what_to_avoid: Avoid relying solely on SEO tricks; focusing on quality content and user experience is crucial for sustainable growth.
optimization_tips: Break down coding problems into smaller sub-problems; this method can lead to more efficient coding practices and faster problem resolution.

top_comments.author: emil_sorensen
top_comments.text: OP here. It's kind of ironic that making the docs AI-friendly essentially just ends up being what good documentation is in the first place (explicit context and hierarchy, self-contained sections, precise error messages).

top_comments.author: shafyy
top_comments.text: It's the same for SEO also. Good structure, correct use of HTML elements, quick loading, good accessibility, etc. Sure, there are "tricks" to improve your SEO, but the general principles are also good if you were not doing SEO.

top_comments.author: klysm
top_comments.text: And yet in practice SEO slop garbage is SEO slop garbage. Devoid of any real meaning or purpose other than to increase rankings and metrics. Nobody cares if it’s good or useful, but it must appease the algorithm!

top_comments.author: jilles
top_comments.text: It's similar for writing code. Suddenly people are articulating their problems to the LLM and breaking it down in smaller sub-problems to solve....

top_comments.author: arscan
top_comments.text: In other words, people are discovering the value of standard software engineering practices. Which, I think is a good thing.

top_comments.author: corysama
top_comments.text: It has changed how I structure my code. Out of laziness, if I can write the code in such a way that each step follows naturally from what came before, "the code just writes itself!" Except now it's literally true :D

top_comments.author: appreciatorBus
top_comments.text: Maybe everyone already discovered this but I find that if I include a lot of detail in my variables names, it's much more likely to autocomplete something useful. If whatever I typed was too verbose for my liking long term, I can always clean it up later with a rename.

top_comments.author: bobbiechen
top_comments.text:
Related: "If an AI agent can't figure out how your API works, neither can your users" (from my employer's blog)
https://stytch.com/blog/if-an-ai-agent-cant-figure-out-how-y...

top_comments.author: Cthulhu_
top_comments.text:
It's a good tool to use for code reviewing, especially if you don't have peers with Strong Opinions on it.
Which is another issue, indifference. It's hard to find people that actually care about things like API design, let alone multiple that check each other's work. In my experience, a lot of the time people just get lazy and short-circuit the reviews to "oh he knows what he's doing, I'm sure he thought long and hard about this".

top_comments.author: thom
top_comments.text: Yeah, I've started to think AI smoke tests for cognitive complexity should be a fundamental part of API/schema design now. Even if you think the LLMs are dumb, Stupidity as a Service is genuinely useful.

business_opportunities.description: Develop AI documentation tools focusing on RAG frameworks.
business_opportunities.target_market: AI developers and organizations implementing RAG.

competitive_intelligence.strategic_moves: Kapa's focus on structured documentation enhances AI performance.
competitive_intelligence.market_impact: Sets a standard for documentation quality in AI, influencing competitors.

investment_insights.investment_angle: Invest in companies creating AI documentation solutions.
investment_insights.risk_factors: Market saturation and evolving AI standards.
investment_insights.potential_returns: High demand could yield returns within 1-3 years.

actionable_takeaways: Adopt standardized semantic HTML for AI documentation.
Shift from PDFs to HTML or Markdown for better machine readability.

key_metrics.growth_indicators: Rising adoption of RAG frameworks in AI.
key_metrics.market_size: Increasing investment in AI documentation tools.

stories.title: Fang, the CLI Starter Kit
stories.author: bewuethr
stories.article_summary: Fang is an experimental CLI starter kit designed for Cobra applications, offering features such as fully styled help pages, error messages, and automatic versioning. It includes a hidden command for generating manpages using Mango, which enhances the appearance of documentation by utilizing roff instead of markdown. The library allows for customizable themes, supports silent usage output to improve user experience, and is easy to implement with a simple invocation of `fang.Execute` alongside a Cobra command. As part of the Charm ecosystem, Fang is open-source under the MIT license, inviting community feedback and contributions via platforms like Twitter and Discord.

agreement_points: The community agrees that cross-compilation is significantly easier in Go compared to Rust, as evidenced by multiple comments highlighting the simplicity of setting environment variables in Go versus the complexities faced in Rust.
comments_analysis.sentiment_summary: The discussion highlights the challenges of cross-compilation in Rust compared to Go, with community members emphasizing the ease of Go's static linking. Tools like Goreleaser are praised for their utility in simplifying deployment processes for Go applications, while the complexities of Rust's dynamic linking are acknowledged as a significant hurdle for developers.
comments_analysis.top_comment_summary: The commenter highlights that maintaining rust-starter, a Rust equivalent of fang, has revealed that cross-compiling for different operating systems (Linux, macOS, Windows) is the most challenging aspect of developing a command-line interface (CLI). They note that unlike web back-ends, where the execution environment is controlled, CLIs must accommodate diverse user environments.

tools_mentioned: Goreleaser is discussed as a tool for creating GitHub releases, Homebrew packages, Docker images, and Linux packages, streamlining the deployment process for Go applications and reducing the manual effort involved in packaging.

compatibility_issues: Rust's dynamic linking requires system libraries which complicates cross-compilation, while Go's static linking simplifies the process, making it easier for developers to target multiple platforms without additional dependencies.

strong_agreements: The community agrees that cross-compilation is significantly easier in Go compared to Rust, as evidenced by multiple comments highlighting the simplicity of setting environment variables in Go versus the complexities faced in Rust.
expert_opinions: Carlos, the creator of GoReleaser, is recognized for his contributions to the community, including the development of Fang, indicating a strong connection between tool development and community needs.

working_setups: GoReleaser is used successfully in various projects, demonstrating its effectiveness in automating the release process and reducing the overhead associated with manual packaging.

top_comments.author: csomar
top_comments.text:
I’ve been maintaining rust-starter[!] for quite sometime now. It is kind of the equivalent of fang but for Rust. It uses Clap which is the equivalent of Cobra; though I don’t think Clap has the same kind of fancy output?
Throughout these years, I have found that cross-compiling is the most challenging part of creating a CLI. When you are building a web back-end, you control the execution environment (usually linux). For CLIs, your users could be on Linux, macOS or Windows. You need to get three x2 binaries (so a total of 6) to have a fair coverage.
I’ve tried cross, but for Windows and macOS you need licenses. There is no straightforward way to give your users Docker images and have them running in a few commands. You can compile on GitHub action machines, but that’s a very slow feedback loop. I wonder if things are better in Go land.
!: https://github.com/rust-starter/rust-starter

top_comments.author: neomantra
top_comments.text:
Golang itself bundles a toolchain and can cross compile to a many target OSes and architectures. I use Goreleaser [1] to create GitHub releases, Homebrew packages, Docker images, and Linux packages. Goreleaser Pro can also create MSI packages.
ETA since I just saw Christian chime in: the Goreleaser author works at Charm.sh =)
[1] https://goreleaser.com

top_comments.author: christianrocha
top_comments.text:
GoReleaser is indeed an awesome tool and we use it for every applicable project.
And actually Carlos, who builds GoReleaser, is the true author of Fang and took it from concept to execution.

top_comments.author: threemux
top_comments.text: Wow TIL cross compilation is a bit of a pain in Rust. I assumed it was as easy as Go. I can confirm as long as you're using pure Go (no cgo), it's as easy as setting $GOOS and $GOARCH appropriately.

top_comments.author: paulddraper
top_comments.text:
The difficulty is due to Rust dynamically linking and Go statically linking. The former requires the system libs.
That said, I am unfamiliar with any licensing for Windows builds.
MacOS has some niche (usually discarded) technicalities like you can only use the SDK on Apple hardware.

top_comments.author: threemux
top_comments.text: I think that's a reference to the use of Docker in the "cross" tool that makes cross compilation easier but I'm not certain

top_comments.author: christianrocha
top_comments.text:
I feel your pain. That said, cross compiling from Go is pretty trivial, as long as everything is pure Go, which it most often is. That’s one if the reasons we invested in jt.
(Hello from Charm! I’m one of the authors of this library.)

top_comments.author: mootoday
top_comments.text:
This is great, lots I learned by looking at your code and the dependencies you use!
I started a similar thing, although not as feature-rich as yours. My goal was to follow CLI best practices and add all the boilerplate one needs to build a Rust CLI.
https://github.com/mootoday/cli-template

top_comments.author: rmac
top_comments.text:
I looked into how rust does does it for rustup, and they have a pretty amazing set of gh actions to build for their architectures, I can't find the GH link now tho
for speed you can look for vendors like https://depot.dev/

top_comments.author: johnisgood
top_comments.text:
I just ran across "gum"[1] from charmbracelet which I intend to use! I just want to replace dialog. I came across whiptail, too, but gum seems nicer.
They have a TUI framework, too, among a lot of other related things. Some of their projects are Go libraries, some are a CLI tool, such as gum.
[1] https://github.com/charmbracelet/gum

actionable_insights_summary.summary:
**Executive Summary:**

Texas Instruments' $60B investment in U.S. semiconductor manufacturing signals a significant opportunity to address supply chain challenges; businesses should consider partnerships with TI and invest in R&D for production-enhancing technologies. Additionally, the rising demand for AI documentation tools, particularly those utilizing RAG frameworks, presents a chance to develop standardized, machine-readable documentation solutions. Lastly, the increasing interest in CLI tools like Fang highlights a market opportunity to create user-friendly CLI solutions for Go and Rust, emphasizing community engagement for development feedback.
